reviewText:
This is the only film in which Key Luke, who is best known as Charlie Chan's number one son, plays a lead role.
It is a fun example of the genre and combines humor with mystery.

Entertaining oldie mystery. Quality of picture/audio good. Always enjoy Keye Luke as a character actor. He was great in the Charlie Chan series as well if you like this type of detective "who dun-its".

Six films featuring the character James Lee Wong were produced between 1938 and 1940.  In the first five films, Wong, a detective, was played by Boris Karloff (1887-1969), who was not Chinese.  However in the final entry in the series, Phantom of Chinatown (1940), Keye Luke (1904-1991) assumed the role.  Luke was well known for playing Lee Chan, the son of the famous detective Charlie Chan in a number of films, and he brings to the role of Wong, an authentic ethnicity, and youthful enthusiasm that was absent with Karloff.

Doctor Benton, a famous archeologist has just returned from an expedition to Mongolia.  While there, Benton had discovered an ancient scroll, is just about to report his findings at a conference at a university, when he passes out.  Benton later dies, the victim of poison.  Police Captain Street (Grant Withers) takes charge of investigating the murder, and discovers that the scroll is missing.  Wong, a friend of Benton's daughter Louise (Virginia Carpenter), works with Street, and Benton's secretary Win Len (Lotus Long), to try and solve the murder, and recover the scroll.

Keeping you guessing until the end, Phantom of Chinatown is a fairly enjoyable watch for fans of mysteries from this era.  At a time when Caucasian actors typically played Asian characters like Mr. Moto, and Charlie Chan, this movie is notable because Keye Luke who is actually Asian, is featured in the lead role.  Luke's portrayal of Wong is more stylish, and refreshingly mostly free of ethnic stereotypes.  Also interesting is that Wong meets Captain Street, a reoccurring character in the previous films, for the first time, and this was the fourth appearance in a Detective Wong movie for actress Win Lin.

Not only has Keye Luke played the number one son Lee in the Chinese detective films of Charlie Chan, but he also starred as a detective himself - James Lee Wong! The Wong series was taken over by Boris Karloff as the Chinese detective in later years (for some weird reason!), yet Keye was the first. In this story, an archeological expedition discovers an ancient Chinese tomb that holds a secret that could be vital to the defense of China today. The leader of the expedition suddenly dies while drinking water at a lecture. All we know is that someone in the expedition did it. But who? This Wong film is not nearly as entertaining as the Chan films, despite the appearance of Keye Luke, who plays the lead role. There is much in the ways of Chinese proverbs as a confused San Francisco detective (Grant Withers) tries to make sense of it all. The murderer was not too hard to figure out, though the "missing pilot" who later turns up is still a bit of a plot hole. The use of Chinese culture and language was tastefully done, except for a few "me no do that" kind of talk every once in awhile. Also I did not know there was a separate Chinatown Phone Exchange in San Francisco in those days! Also starring Lotus Long, an Asian actress who had a few roles in those days. Recommended. Other Wong Detective Films: Mr. Wong, Detective - The Complete Collection (Mr. Wong, Detective / The Mystery of Mr. Wong / Mr. Wong in Chinatown / The Fatal Hour / Doomed to Die / Phantom of Chinatown)

"'Phantom of Chinatown' grabbed my attention because I have extensive dealings with Chinese people in my line of work. This movie from the last century gave me a new respect for them while holding me spellbound, too. I guess our own country does suffer from a serious lack of mystery..."

Keye Luke stepped in and played Mr Wong in this entry of the series. Boris Karloff had done a great job playing Wong in the other five Wong movies and this one is more of a "prequel" with Luke in fine form as the young Mr Wong. Good stuff!
Great - lots of fun!

So much fun watching this.  I looked up Keye Luke because I didn't know someone of Asian descent was in so many movies and was portrayed with dignity rather than stereotypes and caricature.  Loved this movie.
Awesome classic
Not a bad movie. It isn't five stars, nor is it as entertaining as Boris Karloff was in the role, but all in all it was enjoyable
Good movie and interesting plot.  Fits nicely in this era of movie making.
A good picture, but after watching the Boris Karloff series, this falls a little short.
Enjoys the movie and would love more.
Just a fun old black and white detective movie.

I realize that most people would not give a Mr. Wong film 5 stars, but I give it that because I love these old movies so much.  Movies of this type make me feel wonderful and this one in particular did a great job in doing that.  I didn't think anyone could be Mr. Wong besides Boris Karloff, but, being a Keye Luke fan, I certainly thought I should give him a try.  He did not disappoint.  The only disappointment is that popularity of the films declined with the departure of Karloff and Luke only starred in one film.  Luke was a wonderful, and grossly underrated, actor.  Delightful film!
weak
Keye Luke is very good as Mr. Won and I kind of wish they had kept him. Was there a prejudice against Orientals?
Old time simplicitic movie.
it's ok
Enjoyable old flick
Great movie for Charlie Chan fans

Incredibly poor acting, with several of the principals rushing their lines and sounding like they were reciting the script for the first time.  The plot, if you can call it that, is inane -- and the lame fight sequence near the very end was so poorly choreographed it was comical.  I love Charlie Chan and The Mysterious Mr. Wong films, but this one is a complete waste of time...
Love my classic movies!
Good old movie
I really like old movies and this one I enjoyed!  The plot is average but I love the clothes and cars from the forties!!
Like.

In this movie, an Asian detective, Mr. Wong, is being played by Keye Luke, an actual Asian.  What a novel idea!  His intelligent, handsome detective is called upon to assist in the murder of an archeologist, a missing scroll, and eternal fire.  Good Saturday afternoon movie with a good cast.

Keye Lucke was one of the original regular Asian stars in Hollywood.to become semi famous. He was I believe in many Charlie Chan movies.originally. I was expecting this movie to highlight his acting skills. However it was extremely whitewashed with the prejudices and culture of time. Very disappointing.

Hard to like black and white programs, but because I am interested in the oldies I enjoyed the movie.  I am guessing that this was made before Karloff did his versions.  Keye Luke did a good job, but I liked the Karloff Wong movies better.
stopped working a quarter of the way into the movie...Thanks
Good mystery! Had me fooled until the end. Only 4 stars as the quality of the film was a little poor.
Worth watching
VERY GOOD, BUT WOULD HAVE BEEN A BETTER MOVIE IF BORIS KARLOFF STARRED
Just a fun old movie
Not a bad flic for the time period lead actor was better as Charley Chan's Number One son.
Love watching old movies - like having a time capsul.
It was okay but not really up to Charlie Chan standards for a mystery plot.
I love these old time movies
Good genre movie.

The end of a Series of Mr. Wong murder mysteries. Mr Wong was portratyed formerly by Boris Karloff. Yes, they finally had an Asian Actor to play a Chinese Detective. Keye Luke, as usual did a good job. But I think this was the first and last time, for him to prortray this role.
Think of those Charlie Chan movies, as this is in the same genre, but not so racist as some black Characters were portrayed in the Chan movies.
This was probably a B Movie back in the 1940's, It's in B&W but the copy here is fine. It's a fun watch if you enjoy old movies. It only runs over an hour or so.

Another grade b movie from a long way back.  I admit to liking black and white movies and sometimes prefer them to full color.  If it is raining you want to try it.  But don't forget, the acting is stiff and the dialogue is juvenile.  Why three stars, it was actually funny in parts.
A rip-roaring, good-time, 1940's B movie classic. Too bad there were not more of these Keye Luke mysteries filmed.
Ok... wish Charlie Chan was there.
Very good  movie oldie but goodie!
The video would not play
Love these old black and white movies

It was nice to have a Chinese person play a Chinese character. Keye Luke also plays a knock off of Charlie Chan and a well acted portrayal of Mr. Wong, whose stories are usually knockoffs of Charlie Chan's movies.

Rather weird having the 6th movie in the series feature a much younger Mr. Wong and it makes Wong and Streets relationship appear as if they just met.  Perhaps this is designed as a surrealistic prequel.  I did like it and reading up on the story behind these movies and how Keye Luke was cast as the lead in this last movie of the series is a story of its own.  I missed Marjorie Reynolds in this one, but still an excellent mystery and very well done.
I like the show it reminded me of some Charlie Chan movies that Keye Luke played in for that period time the movie was good my opinion only
I aways like these old detective movies!
I am a fan of Mr. Wong, but until I saw this one didn't know Keye Luke starred in one. I have to say it is one of the best. Very well done.
entertaining!
Not worth watching except for  Keye Luke.
This low budget item turned out to be a nice, diverting little movie.
Fun old mystery movie
Wonderful old murder mystery not to be missed.

Compared to some of the Charlie Chann movies currently on Amazon Prime, at least this one had Chinese people playing Chinese characters.  This one moved along pretty well, was entertaining, and was somewhat predictable.  Good entertainment.
I really like who done its
These old James Lee Wong movies are still fun.
Low budget mystery. Was still fun to watch. Acting was a little stiff.

I liked this movie a lot.  Why?  Because it was in B & W and there was no sex, no nudity, and no cursing.  I hate this in movies today.  That's why I don't go out to the movies.  I'd rather watch Amazon prime videos.  I love mysteries.

I watched the show for old times sake as they do not make them like that anymore.  I appreciated that it was based more on deduction than the violence of today.  Not the best old movie I have seen, but not bad!
Good oldie.
Good
Great movie, was fun to watch. Keye Luke played the character well.

The thing I liked most about this old Flick is that even though it was made pre WWll, it portrayed the Chinese star character as an intelligent, well spoken and well educated detective, not some stereotype.
Keye Luke. He did better as Charlie Chan's son. You can tell this is one of those movies shot on the lot in 3-5 days.
It was pretty good for an older movie.
Fun prequel to Mr. Wong series.
This is a good old murder mystery.
Loved seeing Keye Luke playing a detective. He was really good at it.
I like the old show much better than the new ones.
good plot and easy to watch
OK  4 old movie
Finally!  An oriental detective played by an oriental.  The story is ,like many of the B quickies, a bit thin.  But it's fun to watch and moves along nicely.
Sorry I wasn't in the mode for reading subtitles
Just typical fun from a 1940's detective movie. Nothing complex, just fun to watch!
Typical of its genre and era.  It was fun to watch especially if you can appreciate early simplistic cinema.
I still enjoy the old movies!
It's  ok, just not that exciting
Love these old movies!  I will watch it again and again!

As other reviewers have written, Keye Luke portrayed a very main-stream detective in this film. I knew I had seen him before, but I had not realized he was in nearly 100 films and hundreds of TV show episodes. From the dialog; "What is this... a spy plot?"  Well, yes, it is, sort of.  I was somewhat surprised (pleasantly) that a studio allowed a non-majority-race actor to play this lead role, and included what at the time would have been considered somewhat cheeky remarks by him (such as comparing digging up a Chinese emperor with digging up George Washington).  I very much enjoyed this film.
Good old time movie.
Good
A wonderful outing from Keye Luke.
Some of the older black and white movies for crime are very good
Like I've said before I love the old mysteries  the fun part is seeing the same actors in different movies

Actually a pretty good mystery considering the date (1935) and the genre (murder mystery).  Also an interesting, and fairly positive, take of Japanese/Chinese Americans in the years before Pearl Harbor, WWII, and Red China.
Good film, stays a mystery right to the end.
Great fun movie and I love the oldies!!
Enjoyable
Old movies are fun to watch. Especially with Charlie Chan's Son.

I like this ok, I think the reason it didn't go over was because it was very reminiscent of Charlie Chan and Keye Luke was called Jimmy in the movie, Jim or James would have been better. You expected to see Charlie walk in and hear Jimmy holler "Pop", " Pop". You could get a little confused on who the characters were, we had to go back to the beginning and find out who was who. Keye Luke did do a good job though.
Good old mystery film.

I love these old movies. This was a fun film. It was a good role for Key Luke after the Chan series with Warner Oland. The reason for the 4 star was due to the somewhat lackluster performance of our leading lady. The film is remastered as well as it could be for something this old. Sound, of course is weaker since this was ages before Dolby and there is not much they can do to perk it up. But that just gives you the flavor of the era. Enjoy!
Good movie.
I enjoy these old movies, so this fits in that line.  It was an enjoyable romp that's not much over an hour.  Recommended.
I like old movies.
Movies from that time period, I enjoy emencely.  I enjoy them so much.
Love classic movies, love Keys Luke
I love old movies
Great film noir!
Love the old mystery movies
Primitivity of early films. Just fun!
